questions.question: What does the universal quantifier ∀ mean?
options: For all, for every, for each
questions.explanation: The universal quantifier ∀ means 'for all' or 'for every'. ∀x P(x) means 'for all x, P(x) is true' or 'P(x) is true for every x in the domain'.

questions.question: What does the existential quantifier ∃ mean?
questions.explanation: The existential quantifier ∃ means 'there exists' or 'there is at least one'. ∃x P(x) means 'there exists an x such that P(x) is true'.

questions.question: How do you negate ∀x P(x)?
questions.explanation: The negation of 'for all x, P(x)' is 'there exists an x such that not P(x)'. Symbolically: ¬∀x P(x) ≡ ∃x ¬P(x). If not all x satisfy P, then at least one x doesn't.

questions.question: How do you negate ∃x P(x)?
questions.explanation: The negation of 'there exists an x such that P(x)' is 'for all x, not P(x)'. Symbolically: ¬∃x P(x) ≡ ∀x ¬P(x). If there's no x satisfying P, then all x don't satisfy P.

questions.question: Does the order of quantifiers matter? For example, is ∀x ∃y P(x,y) the same as ∃y ∀x P(x,y)?
questions.explanation: The order of quantifiers matters! ∀x ∃y P(x,y) means 'for every x, there is some y' (y can depend on x). ∃y ∀x P(x,y) means 'there exists one y that works for all x' (y is fixed). These are different.

questions.question: What is the scope of a quantifier?
options: The portion of the formula where the quantifier applies
questions.explanation: The scope of a quantifier is the part of the formula to which the quantifier applies. It's usually indicated by parentheses: ∀x (P(x) → Q(x)).

questions.question: In the statement ∀x (P(x) → Q(x)), what does this express?
options: If any x has property P, then that x also has property Q
Some x have both P and Q
questions.explanation: ∀x (P(x) → Q(x)) means 'for all x, if P(x) then Q(x)'. This states that whenever P holds for an object, Q must also hold for that object.

questions.question: What is a vacuous truth in the context of universal quantifiers?
options: A universally quantified statement that's true because the domain is empty or the antecedent is always false
questions.explanation: A vacuous truth occurs when ∀x (P(x) → Q(x)) is true because P(x) is false for all x in the domain, making the implication trivially true regardless of Q(x).

questions.question: Can you use the same variable for multiple quantifiers in one formula?
options: Yes, but each occurrence defines a separate binding
No, each variable must be unique
questions.explanation: Yes, you can reuse variable names, but each quantifier creates its own binding. In ∀x P(x) ∧ ∃x Q(x), the two x's are independent and refer to different potential values.

questions.question: What is De Morgan's law for quantifiers?
questions.explanation: De Morgan's laws for quantifiers state that negating a universal quantifier gives an existential quantifier with negated predicate, and vice versa: ¬∀x P(x) ≡ ∃x ¬P(x) and ¬∃x P(x) ≡ ∀x ¬P(x).
